image.altText: Clare Martin looking toward the camera in front of an out of focus "Vote YES" sign.

items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Friday, October 13.

title.children: Former chief minister says a Voice would have prevented NT Intervention

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Evelyn Manfield Leading No campaigner Warren Mundine says he's comfortable Australia will vote No in the referendum, but he still wants people to make sure they turn up and vote if they haven't yet done so. "I've just flown in from Tasmania the day before and I have been in Adelaide, South Australia, [and] everything feels comfortable, but we've got to have people turn up today, we've got to have people vote," he said after casting his vote. Mr Mundine maintained the country did not need to have a referendum in the first place and the money could have been better spent on education, employment and housing. He said after the referendum, he would work with campaigners from the Yes side to fix the struggles Aboriginal people face.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Warren Mundine casts his vote, says he's 'comfortable' Australia will vote No

props.alt: A close up of Warren speaking at the National Press Club

children.content: Warren Mundine
(AAP: Lukas Coch)
By Evelyn Manfield
Leading No campaigner
Warren Mundine
says he's comfortable Australia will vote No in the referendum, but he still wants people to make sure they turn up and vote if they haven't yet done so.

"I've just flown in from Tasmania the day before and I have been in Adelaide, South Australia, [and] everything feels comfortable, but we've got to have people turn up today, we've got to have people vote," he said after casting his vote.
Mr Mundine maintained the country did not need to have a referendum in the first place and the money could have been better spent on education, employment and housing.
He said after the referendum, he would work with campaigners from the Yes side to fix the struggles Aboriginal people face.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Matt Garrick Former Northern Territory chief minister Clare Martin says she believes a Voice to Parliament would have prevented the NT Intervention in 2007, which saw the Australian Federal Police and defence force members sent into remote communities across the territory. More than 15 years since the Intervention, many Aboriginal leaders say it left NT communities disempowered and disenfranchised, and contributed to the level of social issues faced today. Ms Martin was the Labor NT government's leader when then-prime minister John Howard's Coalition triggered the Intervention, to try to combat what it believed at the time was a surge in sexual assaults against children. "If there's ever anywhere that needs a strong national Voice to stop federal governments doing really stupid things in the territory, then it's this Voice," Ms Martin said. "I'm a product of the Intervention, which John Howard did because he wanted to win votes elsewhere. "That was an extraordinary waste of money and a damage for Aboriginal people. "If we had a Voice, we would never have had an Intervention." Mr Howard last week told an Australians for Constitutional Monarchy conference that he defended his government's decision to start the Intervention, saying it was a "recognition that … the Northern Territory government, had completely failed in its responsibilities".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former NT chief minister says a Voice would have prevented NT Intervention

props.alt: Clare Martin looking toward the camera in front of an out of focus YES campaign sign

children.content: Clare Martin.
(ABC News: Tristan Hooft)
By Matt Garrick
Former Northern Territory chief minister
Clare Martin

says she believes a Voice to Parliament would have prevented the NT Intervention in 2007, which saw the Australian Federal Police and defence force members sent into remote communities across the territory.
More than 15 years since the Intervention, many Aboriginal leaders say it left NT communities disempowered and disenfranchised, and
contributed to the level of social issues faced today

Ms Martin was the Labor NT government's leader when then-prime minister John Howard's Coalition triggered the Intervention, to try to combat what it believed at the time was a surge in sexual assaults against children.
"If there's ever anywhere that needs a strong national Voice to stop federal governments doing really stupid things in the territory, then it's this Voice," Ms Martin said.
"I'm a product of the Intervention, which John Howard did because he wanted to win votes elsewhere.
"That was an extraordinary waste of money and a damage for Aboriginal people.
"If we had a Voice, we would never have had an Intervention."
Mr Howard last week told an Australians for Constitutional Monarchy conference
that he defended his government's decision to start the Intervention, saying it was a "recognition that … the Northern Territory government, had completely failed in its responsibilities".

image.altText: Smoke is coming from Gaza following Israeli strikes.

items.synopsis: The Israel Defense Forces take to Telegram to confirm earlier reports from the United Nations that the IDF was warning 1.1 million Gazans to evacuate to the south by midnight. Follow live

title.children: Israel Defense Forces warn over 1 million Gazans to relocate to the south

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) have taken to Telegram to confirm earlier reports from the United Nations saying Israeli military warned Gazans to evacuate to the south by midnight. "The IDF calls for the evacuation of all civilians of Gaza City from their homes southwards for their own safety and protection and move to the area south of the Wadi Gaza," the statement reads. "Civilians of Gaza City, evacuate south for your own safety and the safety of your families and distance yourself from Hamas terrorists who are using you as human shields." IDF spokesman Lieutenant Jonathan Conricus took to X to say that IDF did not want to target Gazan civilians. He reiterated that Palestinians in Gaza should relocate to the enclave's south within the next 24 hours. "We understand that this will take time," he said. "It is not an easy process. "The aim of this evacuation is simply to save lives." Mr Conricus also said Israel was liaising with UN authorities and remained "fully committed" to obeying international conflict law.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IDF confirms call for civilians from Gaza to evacuate south

children.content: The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) have taken to Telegram to confirm earlier reports from the United Nations saying Israeli military warned Gazans to evacuate to the south by midnight.
"The IDF calls for the evacuation of all civilians of Gaza City from their homes southwards for their own safety and protection and move to the area south of the Wadi Gaza," the statement reads.
"Civilians of Gaza City, evacuate south for your own safety and the safety of your families and distance yourself from Hamas terrorists who are using you as human shields."
IDF spokesman Lieutenant Jonathan Conricus took to X to say that IDF did not want to target Gazan civilians.
He reiterated that Palestinians in Gaza should relocate to the enclave's south within the next 24 hours.
"We understand that this will take time," he said.
"It is not an easy process.
"The aim of this evacuation is simply to save lives."
Mr Conricus also said Israel was liaising with UN authorities and remained "fully committed" to obeying international conflict law.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's ambassador to the UN Gilad Erdan has slammed the UN over its response to Israel warning 1.1 million Palestinians living in the north of the Gaza Strip to evacuate by midnight to the south. UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric said earlier that it would be "impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences". "The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded, avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation," he said. Mr Erdan hit back by saying that "the UN's response to Israel's early warning to the residents of Gaza is a disgrace!". Mr Erdan said the UN should focus on condemning Hamas and supporting Israel's right to self-defence. "For many years, the UN turned a blind eye to the arming of Hamas and its use of civilian populations and infrastructure in the Gaza Strip for murder and for stockpiling its weapons," he said. Salama Marouf, head of the Hamas government media office, said the relocation warning was an attempt by Israel "to broadcast and pass on fake propaganda, aiming to sow confusion among citizens and harm our internal cohesion." He added: "We urge our citizens not to engage in these attempts." Reuters/ABC
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's ambassador to the UN slams response to Israel warning 1.1 million Gazans to evacuate

children.content: Israel's ambassador to the UN Gilad Erdan has slammed the UN over its response to
Israel warning 1.1 million Palestinians living in the north of the Gaza Strip to evacuate by midnight to the south
Mr Erdan called the UN's response a 'disgrace'
(Reuters: Mike Segar)
UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric said earlier that it would be "impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences".
"The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded, avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation," he said.
Mr Erdan hit back by saying that "the UN's response to Israel's early warning to the residents of Gaza is a disgrace!".
Mr Erdan said the UN should focus on condemning Hamas and supporting Israel's right to self-defence.
"For many years, the UN turned a blind eye to the arming of Hamas and its use of civilian populations and infrastructure in the Gaza Strip for murder and for stockpiling its weapons," he said.

Salama Marouf, head of the Hamas government media office, said the relocation warning was an attempt by Israel "to broadcast and pass on fake propaganda, aiming to sow confusion among citizens and harm our internal cohesion."
He added: "We urge our citizens not to engage in these attempts."
Reuters/ABC

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations says it has been told by the Israeli military that some 1.1 million Palestinians in Gaza should relocate to the enclave's south within the next 24 hours. However, UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric said that it would be "impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences". "The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded, avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation," he said. Mr Dujarric said the order by the Israeli military also applied to all UN staff and those sheltered in UN facilities, including schools, health centres and clinics.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli military warns over 1 million Gazans to relocate south, United Nations says

children.content: The United Nations says it has been told by the Israeli military that some
1.1 million
Palestinians in Gaza should relocate to the enclave's south within the next 24 hours.
However, UN spokesman
Stephane Dujarric
said that it would be "impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences".
"The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded, avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation," he said.
Mr Dujarric said the order by the Israeli military also applied to all UN staff and those sheltered in UN facilities, including schools, health centres and clinics.
